This was my first rifle 50 years ago. When it was given to me, I was told to use .22 Shorts exclusively, as Long Rifle (maybe High-Velocity?) ammo would cause the breech block to open slightly upon firing. Of course, at the time of design, over 100 years ago, the High-Velocity Long Rifle cartridge did not exist, and I'm not sure whether the issue was occurring with Standard-Velocity long rifle cartridges.

Anyway, as a favor to me, my younger brother took the rifle out without asking about 30 years ago, and was probably firing LRHV ammo when the firing pin broke. The captive portion of the pin (cartridge end) is still present in the breech block, retained by the breech block lever. The rifle has been back-burnered since that time.

It was disassembled by one of us back then, and I thought I had all of the pieces, but just noticed as I went to prep it for sale that the breech block screw and hammer screw are missing; all other parts (albeit only half of the firing pin) are present. The breech block and hammer were placed in position, unretained, for the photos.

The bore/rifling appear to be in excellent shape. The unit has light surface rust on most surfaces, though the only possibility of significant pitting appears to be on the buttplate. Note that, as far as I'm aware, this unit has never been refinished, and I've made no attempt to mitigate the corrosion currently present. There is inlaid into the buttstock a medallion with the name "Robert"; if the buyers name is Robert, that'll be 25 bucks on top of the listed price : )

Numrich has a schematic and list of parts at:

http://www.gunpartscorp.com/Manufacturers/SavageStevensSpringfieldFox-33479/Rifles-40502/1412LittleScout-39683.htm?page=1

though it appears that all parts are currently "Sold Out". Sad, because the firing pin and both screws listed for around $25 total.
